''Bahasa Jawi'' |states=[[Malaysia]], [[Thailand]] |ethnicity=[[Thai Malays]], [[Kelantanese Malay people|Kelantanese Malays]] |region=[[Kelantan]], [[Merapoh]] of ([[Pahang]]), [[Besut]] and [[Setiu]] of ([[Terengganu]]), [[Baling]], [[Sik District|Sik]] and [[Padang Terap]] of ([[Kedah]]), [[Hulu Perak]], [[Pengkalan Hulu]] and [[Grik]] of ([[Perak]]) ([[Malaysia]]) [[Pattani Province|Pattani]], [[Narathiwat Province|Narathiwat]], [[Yala Province|Yala]], [[Songkhla Province|Songkhla]] ([[Thailand]]) |speakers=3 million in Thailand |date=2006 |ref=e18 |speakers2=2 million in Malaysia{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} |familycolor=Austronesian |fam2=[[Malayo-Polynesian languages|Malayo-Polynesian]] (MP) |fam3=[[Nuclear Malayo-Polynesian languages|Nuclear MP]] |fam4=[[Malayo-Sumbawan languages|Malayo-Sumbawan]] |fam5=[[Malayic languages|Malayic]] |fam6=[[Malayan languages|Malayan]] |fam7=[[Malay language|Malay]]? |script=[[Latin script]], [[Arabic Script]] ([[Jawi alphabet|Jawi]]), [[Thai script]] |iso3=mfa |iso3comment=(Pattani) |glotto=patt1249 |glottorefname=Pattani Malay |notice=IPA }} '''Kelantan-Pattani Malay''', often referred to in Thailand as '''Yawi''' (in Thai) or '''Jawi''' (in Patani Malay), and in Kelantan as ''Baso Kelaté'', is an [[Austronesian | Austronesian language ]] and a Malayic / [[Malayan languages|Malayan language]] spoken in the Malaysian state of [[Kelantan]] and the neighbouring southernmost provinces of [[Thailand]]. It is the primary spoken language of [[Thai Malay]]s, but is also used as a [[lingua franca]] by ethnic Southern Thais in rural areas, Muslim and non-Muslim, and the ''samsam'', a mostly Thai-speaking population of mixed Malay and Thai ancestry. Kelantan–Pattani Malay is a highly divergent dialect of [[Malay language|Malay]] because of the geographical isolation of the dialect from the rest of the Malay world by high mountains, deep rainforest and the Gulf of Thailand. In Thailand, it is influenced by Thai. Several varieties exist, but they are mutually comprehensible to the extent that native speakers of Pattani and Kelantanese often cannot differentiate each other. Kelantanese–Pattani Malay is distinct enough that radio broadcasts in Standard Malay cannot be understood easily by native speakers of Kelantanese–Pattani Malay who are not taught the standard language, for example, those in Thailand. Unlike Malaysia where Standard Malay is compulsory in the school curriculum, no one is required to learn Standard Malay in Thailand, and so there is potentially less language influence from standard Malay but potentially more from [[Thai language|Thai]]. It is different also from [[Kedah Malay]] and [[Terengganu Malay|Terengganuan Malay]], but both languages have close similarities with the Kelantanese-Pattani Malay language. ==Names== The language is often referred to in Thai as ''Phasa Yawi'' (Thai: ภาษายาวี {{IPA-th|pʰāːsǎː jāːwīː|}}), which is a corruption of the Malay name for the modified Arabic alphabet for writing Malay, [[Jawi script|Jawi]] (Yawi: جاوي, Rumi: Jawi, {{IPA-xx|dʑaˈwi|IPA}}). It is also referred to in Thai as ''Phasa Malayu Pattani'' (Thai: ภาษามลายูปัตตานี {{IPA-th|pʰāːsǎː mālāːjūː pàttāːnīː|}}) and similarly locally in Malay as ''Bahasa Malayu Patani'' (Jawi: بهاس ملايو ڤطاني, Rumi: Bahasa Melayu Patani, {{IPA-xx|baˈsɔ ˈnːaju ˈtːaniŋ|local}}). The dialect is often simply just called ''Bahasa Patani''. Kelantanese is known in Standard Malay as {{lang|ms|Bahasa Kelantan}}, and in Kelantanese as ''Baso Kelate''. ==Distribution== Pattani Malay is the main language of the provinces of [[Narathiwat]], [[Yala Province|Yala]], [[Pattani]] where the Malay ethnic group is the dominant one. Also some part of [[Songkhla]]. It is less spoken in [[Satun]], where even the ethnic Malays generally speak [[Southern Thai language|Southern Thai]] and [[Kedah Malay]]. It is also spoken in scattered villages as far north as [[Hat Yai]]. In the past, Malay was the main language as far north as the [[Isthmus of Kra]], the traditional division between [[Central Thailand]] and [[Southern Thailand]], based on the preponderance of etymologically Malay place names. Kelantanese is spoken in the state of [[Kelantan]], as well as in [[Besut]] and [[Setiu]] districts of [[Terengganu]] and the [[Perhentian Islands]]. Also in [[Merapoh]] district of [[Pahang]]. Many people in the districts of [[Baling]], [[Sik]] and [[Padang Terap]] in [[Kedah]] as well as [[Grik]] and [[Hulu Perak]] districts of [[Perak]] speak Kelantanese dialects, since most of the Malay people there are the descendants of Kelantanese migrants and Pattani refugees. ==Writing system== Kelantanese Malay has an older and a richer literary history than standard Malay.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} It is written in the [[Jawi alphabet]], based on the [[Arabic script]], which is where the name "Yawi/Jawi" for the language comes from. This is in stark contrast to the rest of the general population of Malay speakers in both [[Malaysia]] and [[Indonesia]] that now use the [[Latin script]], known in Malay as ''rumi'' (رومي), for daily communication. Today, Pattani Malay itself is generally not a written language, though it is sometimes written in informal settings or [[eye dialect]]. When writing is needed, an old-fashioned variety of standard Malay is used rather than the local dialect. A phonetic rendering of Pattani Malay in the [[Thai alphabet]] has been introduced, but it has not met with much success, due to the socio-religious significance of Jawi to Muslim Malays, as well as because of numerous inconsistencies and inaccuracies.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} ==History== [[Southern Thailand]] has continued to be a region affected by two cultural spheres: the mainly Buddhist, Thai-speaking [[Siam]]ese kingdoms and the mainly Muslim, Malay-speaking sultanates. The region was a warehouse of trade where merchants from Europe, India, Arabia, China, Siam, and the other Malay world met. At first dominated by Hindu-Buddhist Indian influences, the great kingdom of [[Srivijaya]] would later fall in chaos. [[Islam]] was introduced by Arab and Indian traders in the 11th century and has been the dominant religion ever since, replacing the Buddhism and Hinduism that had held sway before. By the 14th century, the area became vassals to [[Ayutthaya Kingdom|Ayutthaya]], but the region was autonomous and never fully incorporated into the modern Thai [[nation-state]] till 1902. This political autonomy and isolation from the rest of the Malay world allowed for preservation of the Malay language and culture but also led to the divergence of the dialect. ==Differences between Yawi and Standard Malay== Kelantanese is different enough from Standand Malay that it is often unintelligible to speakers of the standard language. Differences include different vocabulary, but also involve regular sound changes. The influence of Southern Thai and Pattani Malay upon each other is great, and both have large numbers of loanwords from the other. The influence of the Thai language is one factor that makes comprehension between Pattani Malay and Standard Malay difficult. '''Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún''' is a Nigerian linguist, writer, scholar and cultural activist <ref name=":1">{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpressjournal.com/africa/nigeria/nigerian-scholar-creates-online-home-yoruba-names#sthash.ls62m7JM.dpuf|title=Nigerian Scholar Creates an Online Home for Yoruba Names|last=Olofinlua|first=Temitayo|date=25 May 2015|website=Global Press Journal|publisher=Global Press|access-date=|quote="With the help of volunteers and crowdsourcing contributors, he is creating an online compendium of Yoruba names with meanings and aural pronunciations."}}</ref><ref name=":2">[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/ebenezar-wikina/a-stroll-with-kola-tubosu_1_b_9661030.html/ "A Stroll with Kola Tubosun, Teacher, Writer, Linguist and Founder, YorubaName.com"]</ref><ref name=":3">[http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b06qm3mk/ "Writing a New Nigeria: Ideas of Identity"], [[BBC Radio 4]],</ref> whose work and influence span the fields of education, technology, literature, journalism, and linguistics. He is a Fulbright Fellow ([[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]], 2009) and recipient of the 2016 [[Premio Ostana]] "Special Prize" for Writings in the Mother Tongue. (Ostana Premio Scritture in Lingua Madre)<ref name="Utor">{{cite web|url=http://guardian.ng/art/tobosun-receives-international-award-for-mother-tongue-literature-2016/|title=Tobosun Receives International Award For Mother Tongue Literature 2016|date=31 January 2016|website=The Guardian|publisher=|location=Nigeria|access-date=|quote=|author=Florence Utor}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{cite web|first= Ozolua |last=Uhakheme|url=http://thenationonlineng.net/nigerian-author-wins-premio-ostana-award-for-scriptures/|title=Nigerian author wins Premio Ostana award for scriptures|date=25 January 2016|work=The Nation}}</ref><ref name="targatocn.it">{{Cite web|url=http://www.targatocn.it/2016/06/05/leggi-notizia/argomenti/eventi/articolo/giunge-a-conclusione-lottava-edizione-del-premio-ostana.html|title=Giunge a conclusione l'ottava edizione del Premio Ostana|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> He writes in Yoruba and English.
==Bio== Tubosun was born in [[Ibadan]], [[Nigeria]] on 22 September 1981, and holds a Masters in Linguistics from [[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]] (2012) and a BA from the [[University of Ibadan]] (2005). He also studied briefly at [[Moi University]], [[Eldoret]], [[Kenya]], in April 2005, as part of a [[MacArthur Foundation]]-sponsored Socio-Cultural Exchange Programme.
He was granted a [[Fulbright Fellowship|Fulbright scholarship]] in 2009 through which he taught [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] at [[Southern Illinois University Edwardsville]] in 2009–10. In 2010, he worked as a volunteer adult literacy tutor, with resettled immigrants, at the International Institute of [[St. Louis]], Missouri, and later as a high school teacher of [[English language]] in [[Lagos]], [[Nigeria]].
==Language advocacy== === Twitter in Yoruba Campaign === Tubosun is known for his work in language advocacy. In 2012, he started an online campaign to demand that Twitter include [[Yoruba language|Yoruba]] (his mother tongue) in the list of languages into which Twitter was being translated: 1 March 2012 was declared "the Tweet Yoruba Day" to call attention to the matter.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://globalvoices.org/2013/03/06/nigerians-shake-up-twitter-with-yoruba-language-tweets/|title=Nigerians Shake Up Twitter with Yoruba-Language Tweets|last=Egbunike|first=Nwachukwu|date=2013|website=Global Voices}}</ref> The campaign involved other speakers of Yoruba online tweeting only in the language and directing their comments to the Twitter translation platform, and it eventually yielded first an acknowledgment of the protest and then a promise to act in support of the idea.
The campaign continued on 1 March 2013 and again on 1 March 2014. In August 2014, Twitter announced through a tweet that they were now adding Yoruba (along with Esperanto) to the translation platform, ending the two years of advocacy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techloy.com/2012/03/02/twitter-supports-yoruba/|title=Twitter Promises Support For Yoruba in Coming Months|last=Oluwafemi|first=Bankole|date=2 March 2012|website=TechLoy}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://encomium.ng/twitter-can-now-be-translated-into-yoruba/|title=Twitter Can Now be Translated into Yoruba|last=|first=|date=4 December 2014|website=Encomium|publisher=|access-date=|quote=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://techcabal.com/2014/11/14/twitter-yoruba/|title=It Took Only Two Years, But Twitter Is Finally Getting Translated into Yoruba|last=Bankole|first=Oluwafemi|date=14 November 2014|website=TechCabal|publisher=|access-date=|quote="As we speak, Kola and others are working to translate the Twitter's standard glossary of terms."}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201504211070.html/|title=Cultural Export|last=Elusoji|first=Solomon|date=21 April 2015|website=This Day Live/AllAfrica|quote="An online Yoruba dictionary has been launched to help the Yoruba race in Nigeria go beyond borders."}}</ref>
=== The Yoruba Names Project === [[File:Kola Tubosun.jpg|thumb|404x404px|Kola Tubosun as a Fulbright Scholar teaching Yoruba at Southern Illinois University Edwardsville in 2010.]]Tubosun founded the "[[The Yoruba Name Project|Yorùbá Names Project]]" at YorubaName.com in March 2015 after months of crowdfunding as<ref>[http://www.voanews.com/content/online-dictionary-helps-nigerians-decode-their-names/3208016.html/ "Online Dictionary Helps Nigerians Decode Their Names"], ''[[Voice of America]]''.</ref><ref>[http://techcabal.com/2015/03/12/yorubanames-com-hits-crowd-funding-benchmark/ "YorubaName.com Hits Crowdfunding Benchmark"], ''TechCabal''.</ref> an effort to document all names in Yoruba in an accessible multimedia format while bringing together a community of interested linguists and other culture enthusiasts to document the African cultural and linguistic experience on the web. He is also involved in setting up a version for [[Igbo language]] at IgboName.com. On 8 August 2015, the project released a free Yorùbá Keyboard software for Mac and Windows to allow its users type in [[Yoruba language|Yorùbá language]] on the internet<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://radar.techcabal.com/t/yoruba-keyboard-layouts-for-windows-and-mac/1630|title=Yoruba keyboard layouts for Windows and Mac|website=Radar from TechCabal|language=en|access-date=2017-10-20}}</ref> with an update to cater for [[Igbo language|Igbo]] in July 2016.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gadgetsreview.com.ng/yorubaname-team-launch-yoruba-and-igbo-keyboards/|title=Yorubaname Team Launch Yoruba and Igbo keyboards - Gadget Reviews Nigeria|date=2016-07-20|language=en-US|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://technologytimes.ng/combined-igboyoruba-keyboard-layout-now-available/|title=Combined Igbo, Yoruba keyboard made available on Yorubaname.com|date=2016-07-18|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-08-07}}</ref>
In November 2017, the project released the first online speech synthesizer for Yoruba,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.orishaimage.com/blog/yorubatts|title=The Yorùbá Speech Synthesizer|work=Orisha Image|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}}</ref> created after crowdfunding and months of research<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://medium.com/@baroka/what-were-building-next-8b34f7ff545c|title=What We’re Building Next|date=2017-03-14|website=Medium|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.okayafrica.com/culture-2/yoruba-text-to-speech-app/|title=A Yoruba Text-to-Speech App Is Being Brought to Life Through This New Tech Initiative|date=2017-03-23|work=OkayAfrica|access-date=2017-03-23|language=en-US}}</ref> In December 2017, in collaboration with the Orisha Image Blog, the project released a free Yoruba learning audio course.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.okayafrica.com/free-multilingual-audio-course-yoruba-language-olorisha/|title=This Multilingual Audio Course Is a Free Guide to Yoruba for Olorishas Around the World|date=2018-01-11|work=OkayAfrica|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.orishaimage.com/blog/course|title=Yorùbá Melody Audio Course|work=Orisha Image|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Work at Google === Between October 2015 and July 2016, Tubosun worked as a Linguist at [[Google]] with the Speech team as Project Manager.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.yorubaname.com/2016/12/16/e%e1%b9%a3u-isnt-the-devil-but-you-knew-that-already/|title="Èṣù" isn’t "the Devil"; But You Knew That Already|date=2016-12-16|website=Yoruba Name|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.orishaimage.com/blog/kola-tubosun|title=Interview with Yoruba writer Kola Tubosun|access-date=2017-01-09|newspaper=Orisha Image}}</ref>
While at Google, he was also instrumental to changing the erstwhile inaccurate translation of [[Eshu|Esu]] on Google Translate,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://blog.yorubaname.com/2016/12/16/e%e1%b9%a3u-isnt-the-devil-but-you-knew-that-already/|title="Èṣù" isn’t "the Devil"; But You Knew That Already|date=2016-12-16|website=Yoruba Name|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref> which had hitherto caused a lot of backlash in the Yoruba language community.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://ooduarere.com/news-from-nigeria/breaking-news/esu-is-not-satan-2016-awareness/|title=Esu Is Not Satan 2016 Awareness|work=Ọmọ Oòduà|access-date=2017-03-23|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.orishaimage.com/blog-gallery/esu-is-not-satan|title=Esu is not Satan|work=Orisha Image|access-date=2017-03-23|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Writing career== Tubosun has contributed to Nigerian writing since 2005, through poetry, travel writing, essay, prose, and literary criticism. His work has appeared in the International Literary Quarterly, Sentinel Poetry, [[Brittle Paper]], Ake Review and [[Enkare Review]].
=== Poetry === In September 2005, Tubosun released a chapbook of poems called ''Headfirst into the Meddle,'' to a limited audience. In 2015, he followed it with ''Attempted Speech & Other Fatherhood Poems'',<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sarabamag.com/a-fathers-apprehensions-and-fascinations-interview-with-kola-tubosun/ | title = A Father's Apprehensions and Fascinations—Interview with Kola Tubosun |last=Achieng |first=Emily |date=30 September 2015 |website=Saraba Magazine |publisher=Saraba }}</ref> published by [[Saraba Magazine]]. It contains poems written about the experience of raising a child.
In October 2006, his poem "Here, Moving" won the Sentinel Poetry Bar Challenge.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sentinelpoetry.org.uk/1206/kola_tubosun.html|title=4th Anniversary Issue: Sentinel Poetry Online #49 -kola tubosun|website=www.sentinelpoetry.org.uk|access-date=2017-03-16}}</ref>
In 2018, he announced the publication of his first full collection of poems ''Edwardsville by Heart'' (November 2018), a travelogue-memoir to be published by Wisdom's Bottom Press, UK.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ktravula.com/2018/08/poetry-collection-edwardsville-by-heart/|title=Poetry Collection: “Edwardsville by Heart”|date=2018-08-11|work=ktravula - a travelogue!|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Blogging and travel writing === Since 2009, Tubosun has blogged at KTravula.com to document travel, teaching, writing, and student experiences in the [[United States]], [[Nigeria]], and other places.
In 2010, he contributed to [[234Next]] as a travel writer.
In October 2015, he was nominated for the [[CNN]] African Journalists Award<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.olisa.tv/2015/09/kola-tubosun-and-four-other-nigerians-among-finalists-in-the-2015-cnn-multichoice-african-journalist/|title=Kola Tubosun and four other Nigerians among finalists in the 2015 CNN Multichoice African Journalist|last=Adaokoye|first=Ukamaka|date=September 14, 2015|work=Olisa.TV|access-date=March 16, 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=}}</ref> for his travel piece ''Abeokuta's Living History'', first published at KTravula.com. He was the first ever blogger on the award shortlist.
In September 2018, he accompanied [[Brandon Stanton]] from [[Humans of New York]] as a guide while the latter was in Nigeria.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.kanyidaily.com/2018/09/gala-seller-who-gave-out-his-goods-to-prisoners-meets-humans-of-new-york-founder-shares-his-experience-as-a-prisoner.html/|title=Gala Seller Who Gave out his goods to prisoners meets Humans of New York Founder, Shares his experience as a prisoner.|date=2018-09-27|work=KanyiDaily|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Editing === From 2012 to 2015, Tubosun worked as the pioneering editor of a Literary Magazine of new writing from Nigerian and Africa called ''NTLitMag''.
In November 2015, he co-edited as well as ''Aké Review'', the literary publication of the [[Aké Arts and Book Festival]], with Kolade Arogundade.
From 2015–2016, while he taught as a schoolteacher, he edited two issues of ''The Sail'', an anthology of creative works of high school students.<ref name="brittlepaper.com">[http://brittlepaper.com/2015/08/review-sail-literary-publication-whitesands-school-2/ "Review of The Sail | An Anthology of Writings by Students in a Lagos Secondary School"], Brittle Paper, 24 August 2015.</ref><ref name="sabinews.com">[http://www.sabinews.com/first-breath-from-whitesand-a-review-by-tade-ipadeola/ "First Breath From Whitesands: A review by Tade Ipadeola"], ''Sabi News'', 3 July 2015.</ref><ref name="olisa.tv">{{Cite web|url=http://www.olisa.tv/2016/05/24/the-sail-whitesands-schools-launch-2nd-edition-of-students-creativity-compendium/|title=The Sail: Whitesands Schools Launch 2nd Edition of Students’ Creativity Compendium|access-date=2016-05-24}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.sabinews.com/whitesands/|title=Whitesands students bring magic in the second edition of 'The Sail'|date=25 May 2016|website=Sabi News|language=en-GB|access-date=2016-05-25}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://nationalmirroronline.net/new/our-students-literary-works-yielding-results/|title=Our students literary works yielding results|website=National Mirror|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://brittlepaper.com/2016/06/meet-future-african-literature/|title=Whitesands School Celebrates the Next Generation of African Writers|date=2016-06-01|website=Brittle Paper|language=en-US|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref>
=== Literary criticism === [[File:Kolatubosun.jpg|thumb|400x400px|Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún at a recent book panel. Photo courtesy Ake Arts and Book Festival 2016 ]]His work of literary criticism has appeared in the ''NTLitMag, Aké Review,'' Brittle Paper, and [[Enkare Review]].
In 2016, he wrote the entry on [[Nnedi Okorafor]]'s science fiction novel ''Lagoon'' for "Imaginary Wonderlands" (October, 2016), a collection of essays about invented worlds in literature from around the globe, from Dante to Rushdie. The book was edited by [[Laura Miller (writer)]].
=== Translations === Tubosun's work in localizing the predictive text input product "T9" was detailed in a memoir/ essay for [[Farafina Magazine]] in 2007 titled "Speaking the Machine".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/farafina/docs/f_12|title=Farafina 12|access-date=2016-11-27|newspaper=issuu}}</ref>
In February 2014, he was part of the [[Cassava Republic Press]] Ankara Press Valentine Anthology, which had short stories about love by African writers translated into local languages.<ref>[http://brittlepaper.com/2015/02/african-love-stories-ankara-press/ "African Love Stories Ankara Press"], Brittle Paper, February 2016.</ref>
In November 2016, at the [[Aké Arts and Book Festival]], he was instrumental in translating a short story by Kenyan writer [[Ngũgĩ wa Thiong'o]] into [[Yoruba language]],<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://jaladaafrica.org/2016/03/22/jalada-translation-issue-01-ngugi-wa-thiongo/|title=Jalada Translation Issue 01: Ngũgĩ wa Thiong’o|last=Jalada|date=2016-03-22|website=Jalada|access-date=2017-04-27}}</ref> part of which he read out at the festival.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://thenewsnigeria.com.ng/2016/11/ngugi-wa-thiongo-ake-arts-and-book-festivals-worthy-headliner/|title=Ngugi wa Thiong’o: Ake Arts and Book Festival’s Worthy Headliner|date=2016-11-25|access-date=2016-11-27|language=en-US|newspaper=The NEWS}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://guardian.ng/art/abeokuta-a-feast-of-books-arts-on-the-rock/|title=Abeokuta… a feast of books, arts on the rock|access-date=2016-11-27}}</ref>
=== Journalism === Tubosun was the president of the Union of Campus Journalists at [[University of Ibadan]] (2002-2004) during <nowiki/>which time he helped institute two prizes for student journalists, as well as set up the first internship opportunities for student journalists with prominent media houses in the country. Some students from that program became full-time journalists upon graduation.
In September 2016, after the demolition of [[Ilojo Bar]], a national monument on Lagos Island, he published a three-part investigative feature in the Nigerian Guardian about the causes, cost, and consequences of the demolition.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://guardian.ng/sunday-magazine/demolishing-history/|title=Demolishing history|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://guardian.ng/art/a-tragedy-of-confusing-interests/|title=A tragedy of confusing interests|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://guardian.ng/art/a-failure-all-around/|title=A failure all around|access-date=2017-03-08|language=en-US}}</ref>
=== Writing activism and advocacy === In 2003, during a nine-month strike of the Academic Staff Union of Universities, Tubosun created a petition online admonishing the president and minister of education in Nigeria and warning them of the dangers of a continued elongation of the industrial strike to students and the educational system.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200304160127.html|title=Nigeria: Hi-Tech: Students Fight ASUU Strike @ Petitiononline|date=2003-04-16|work=Vanguard (Lagos)|access-date=2017-03-08}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/200305040012.html|title=Nigeria: Students, Other Stakeholders Seek End to ASUU Strike|date=2003-05-04|work=Vanguard (Lagos)|access-date=2017-03-08}}</ref>
In November 2016, after the election of [[Donald Trump]], he co-wrote a petition to restate "our respect for the dignity of people of all races, faiths, creeds, classes, abilities, ancestries, gender identities, and sexual orientations" and express support for the goals of the Fulbright Program "to bring a little more knowledge, a little more reason, and a little more compassion into world affairs and thereby increase the chance that nations will learn at last to live in peace and friendship" warning that cuts to the program will jeopardize its goals.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/an-open-letter-from-1500-fulbrighters-regarding-the_us_582b14aee4b02b1f5257a91b|title=An Open Letter From 1,500+ Fulbrighters Regarding The Election Of Trump|last=Tubosun|first=Kola|last2=Dinh|first2=Claire|date=2016-11-15|website=Huffington Post|language=en-US|access-date=2017-03-21|last3=Downs|first3=Benjamin}}</ref> The petition was signed by about 2000 [[Fulbright Program]] grantees and alumni. The [[Fulbright Program]] has so far survived the proposed cut to the US government budget.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2017/03/15/us/politics/trump-budget-proposal.html|title=Who Wins and Loses in Trump’s Proposed Budget|last=Parlapiano|first=Alicia|date=2017-03-15|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-03-21|last2=Aisch|first2=Gregor|issn=0362-4331}}</ref>
==Honours and awards==
[[File:Premio Ostana.jpg|thumb|The Premio Ostana, a glass-art sculpture and a medal, created by Silvio Vigliaturo, a famous contemporary Italian artist and glass sculptor.]]
=== Tech Innovator === He has been listed in 2015 and 2016 in the [[YNaija]] list of Nigeria's innovators in technology <ref>{{cite web|url=http://ynaija.com/class-2015-nigerias-100-innovative-persons-technology/|title=The class of 2015: Nigeria's 100 most innovative persons in Technology|last=Stephen|first=Jewel|date=2015|website=YNaija|publisher=|access-date=16 March 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ynaija.com/ytech100-ynaija-presents-the-class-of-2016-the-definitive-list/|title=YNaija presents the class of 2016: Nigeria's 100 most innovative persons in Technology|last=Oyetimein|first=Oluwapelumi|date=2016|website=|access-date=26 February 2016|work=YNaija}}</ref>
In 2016, he was named in the [[Quartz (publication)|Quartz]] African Innovator's List.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://qz.com/724308/quartz-africa-innovators-2016/#Tunbosun|title=Quartz Africa Innovators 2016 list|language=en-US|access-date=2016-07-07}}</ref> He was also listed in the "40 Under 40" Innovators for 2017 by Ventures Africa.
=== Premio Ostana === In January 2016, he was chosen as a recipient of a [[Premio Ostana]] "Special Prize" for Mother Tongue Literature (Il Premio Ostana Internazionale Scritture in Lingua Madre 2016), a prize given to any individual who has done writing and notable advocacy for the defence of an indigenous language.<ref name="Utor" /><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sabinews.com/kola-tubosun-becomes-first-african-win-premio-ostana-international-language-award/ | title = KỌ́LÁ TÚBỌ̀SÚN becomes first African to win Premio Ostana international language award | last = | first = | date =26 January 2016 | website = Sabi News | publisher =}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.mirrorng.com/nigerian-man-becomes-first-african-to-win-the-premio-ostana-international-award-for-mother-tongue-literature/ | title = Nigerian Man becomes first African to win the Premio Ostana International Award for Mother Tongue Literature |last = NG |first = Mirror | date = 26 January 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = http://newtelegraphonline.com/tubosun-wins-premio-ostana-international-award/ | title = Tubosun wins Premio Ostana International Award | work =New Telegraph |first = Tony| last=Okuyeme | date =29 January 2016}}</ref> The prize ceremony was held from 2 to 5 June 2016, in the town of [[Ostana]] ([[Province of Cuneo|Cuneo]], Italy).<ref name="targatocn.it" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.it/2016/05/24/festival-ostana-lingue_n_10106262.html|title=Dalla lingua Yoruba allo shar-chicham, nel borgo occitano di Ostana un festival per salvare le lingue minori|website=L'Huffington Post|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2016/06/03/edizioni/cuneo/scritture-in-lingua-madre-un-patrimonio-da-salvare-P1UXPhPQZxA7uxOtX1RX3L/pagina.html|title=Scritture in lingua madre Un patrimonio da salvare|website=LaStampa.it|access-date=2016-06-06}}</ref> Tubosun was the first African to be so honoured by the organisation.
=== Culture Summit === In April 2017, Tubosun joined "nearly 300 participants from over 80 countries around the world, including key players involved in the fields of government, arts, philanthropy, heritage preservation, education, media, science and technology" at [[Saadiyat Island]] in [[Abu Dhabi]], to "explore... a wide range of topics all focused on answering how cultural tools can be used to help address significant international challenges and seize emerging opportunities." It was the first edition of the [[Culture Summit Abu Dhabi|Culture Summit]], sponsored by [[Foreign Policy Magazine]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.gulftoday.ae/portal/36c185bd-6d7a-48b7-ac39-fa62e51f97e9.aspx|title=gulftoday.ae {{!}} Summit to bring creative leaders|website=www.gulftoday.ae|access-date=2017-05-05}}</ref>
=== Pyeongchang Humanities Forum === Tubosun was one of the 160 writers and artists countries invited from eighteen countries around the world to participate in the "Cultural Olympics" in [[Seoul]] and [[Pyeongchang]], preceding the 2018 Winter Olympics. The event aimed "to bring the world together through sport, writers at the event are sharing their ideas on how to tackle some of the difficulties around the world<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://koreajoongangdaily.joins.com/news/article/article.aspx?aid=3043579|title=Writers focus on humanities : Forum brings together literature professionals from around the world|website=Korea JoongAng Daily|access-date=2018-02-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.pyeongchang2018.com/en/news/young-writers-from-18-countries-to-discuss-peace-at-pyeongchang-forum|title=Young Writers from 18 Countries to Discuss Peace at PyeongChang Forum|last=administrator|access-date=2018-02-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
==Selected works== '''Poetry'''
*''Edwardsville by Heart'' (ISBN: 9780993550232) Wisdom's Bottom Press, UK, 2018
*''Attempted Speech and Other Fatherhood Poems'' (Poetry Chapbook) Saraba Magazine, 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sarabamag.com/attempted-speech-and-other-fatherhood-poems/|website=Saraba Magazine|title=Attempted Speech and Other Fatherhood Poems|date=30 September 2015|accessdate=30 September 2015}}</ref>
'''Edited'''
*''Edo North: Field Studies of the Languages and Lands of the Northern Edo'' (Ed., 2011). Essays in Honour of Professor Ben O. Elugbe. Zenith Book House.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://library.soas.ac.uk/Record/789630/|website=SOAS|title=Edo North: Field Studies of the Languages and Lands of the Northern Edo: Essays in Honour of Professor Ben O. Elugbe}}</ref> *''The Sail: Issue 1'' (Ed., March 2015), Whitesands School, Lekki<ref name="brittlepaper.com" /><ref name="sabinews.com" /><ref name="Whitesands Boys Write Book">Belo-Osagie, Kofoworola, [http://thenationonlineng.net/whitesands-boys-write-book/ "Whitesands Boys Write Book"], ''The Nation'', 2 July 2015.</ref><ref name="nationalmirroronline.net">[http://nationalmirroronline.net/new/whitesands-school-grooms-creative-students/ "Whitesands School Grooms Creative Students"], ''National Mirror'', 2 July 2015.</ref> *''The Sail: Issue 2'' (Ed., May 2016), Whitesands School, Lekki<ref name="olisa.tv" />
;Translations * "Arábìnrin Inú Asọ Ọlọsàn. Short Story by [[Sarah Ladipo Manyika]]" (February 2015), Ankara Press Anthology * "Sátidé Létí Òkun – Saturday by the Sea" (2014). Three Poems by Fred D’Aguiar. ''Ake Review'' * "Ọkùnrín tó n dágbé àti ìkookò – The Hermit and the Fox" (2010). Short story by Klemen Pisk * "Volta. Poem by Richard Berengarten" (November 2009),'' International Literary Quarterly'', Issue #9
'''Essays''' * A House for Mr. Soyinka<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://popula.com/2018/08/24/a-house-for-mr-soyinka/|title=A House for Mr. Soyinka|website=Popula|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-12}}</ref> (August 2018) in Popula *In The Shadow of Context.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://enkare.org/in-the-shadow-of-context/|title=In The Shadow of Context {{!}} Enkare Review|date=2017-03-20|work=Enkare Review|access-date=2017-03-20|language=en-GB}}</ref> Essay on Enkare Review * On African Languages and Literature: Lessons from Korea<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://agbowo.org/on-african-languages-and-literature-lessons-from-korea-kola-tubosun/|title=On African Languages and Literature: Lessons from Korea {{!}} Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún|date=2018-04-17|work=Agbowó|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref> *Another Kind of Poverty Gap: The Erosion of Language Diversity<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://opinion.premiumtimesng.com/2018/01/21/another-kind-of-poverty-gap-the-erosion-of-language-diversity-by-kola-tubo%E1%B9%A3un/|title=Another Kind of Poverty Gap: The Erosion of Language Diversity, By Kọ́lá Túbọ̀ṣún|date=2018-01-21|work=Premium Times Opinion|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref> *Complementary ‘Insularity’ as a Language Development Strategy<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://opinion.premiumtimesng.com/2018/02/27/complementary-insularity-as-a-language-development-strategy-by-kola-tubosun/|title=Complementary ‘Insularity’ as a Language Development Strategy, By Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún|date=2018-02-27|work=Premium Times Opinion|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref> *“Lingua Fracas” as a Positive<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://opinion.premiumtimesng.com/2016/06/03/lingua-fracas-as-a-positive-by-kola-tubosun/|title=“Lingua Fracas” as a Positive, By Kọ́lá Túbọ̀sún|date=2016-06-03|work=Premium Times Opinion|access-date=2018-10-07|language=en-US}}</ref>

{{linguistics}} '''Literal and figurative language''' is a distinction within some fields of [[language]] analysis, in particular [[Stylistics (field of study)|stylistics]], [[rhetoric]], and [[semantics]]. *'''Literal language''' uses words exactly according to their conventionally accepted [[meaning (linguistics)|meaning]]s or [[denotation]]. *'''Figurative''' (or '''non-literal''') '''language''' uses words in a way that deviates from their conventionally accepted definitions in order to convey a more complicated meaning or heightened effect.<ref>"[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/figure%20of%20speech Figure of speech]." ''Merriam-Webster Dictionary''. Merriam-Webster, Inc. 2015.</ref> Figurative language is often created by presenting words in such a way that they are equated, compared, or associated with normally unrelated meanings.
Literal usage confers meaning to words, in the sense of the meaning they have by themselves, outside any figure of speech.<ref name="JaszczoltTurner2003">{{cite book|last1=Jaszczolt|first1=Katarzyna M..|last2=Turner|first2=Ken|title=Meaning Through Language Contrast. Volume 2|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ToPN1kTaBMUC&pg=PA141|accessdate=20 December 2012|date=2003-03-01|publisher=John Benjamins Publishing|isbn=9781588112071|pages=141–}}</ref> It maintains a consistent meaning regardless of the context,<ref name="Glucksberg2001">{{cite book|last=Glucksberg|first=Sam|title=Understanding Figurative Language:From Metaphor to Idioms: From Metaphor to Idioms|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rKX7qcQerLcC|accessdate=20 December 2012|date=2001-07-26|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195111095}}</ref> with ''the intended meaning corresponding exactly to the meaning'' of the individual words.<ref name="Harley2001">{{cite book|last=Harley|first=Trevor A.|title=The Psychology of Language: From Data to Theory|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yKbAhoSFcbwC&pg=PA293|accessdate=20 December 2012|year=2001|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=978-0-863-77867-4|pages=293–}}</ref> Figurative use of language is the use of words or phrases that ''implies a non-literal meaning which does make sense or that could [also] be true''.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Montgomery|first1=Mar|last2=Durant|first2=Alan|last3=Fabb|first3=Nigel |author4=Tom Furniss |author5=Sara Mills|title=Ways of Reading: Advanced Reading Skills for Students of English Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhrYfYdHuN8C&pg=PA117|accessdate=23 December 2012|year=2007|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9780415346337|pages=117–}}</ref>
[[Aristotle]] and later the Roman [[Quintilian]] were among the early analysts of [[rhetoric]] who expounded on the differences between literal and figurative language.<ref>{{cite book|DUPLICATE_title=|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SUEtEa9nUWQC&pg=PA129|title=A Glossary of Literary Terms|publisher=Cengage Learning|year=2011|isbn=9780495898023|edition=10|author1=M.H. Abrams|author2=Geoffrey Harpham}}</ref>
In 1769, [[Frances Brooke]]'s novel ''The History of Emily Montague'' was used in the earliest ''Oxford English Dictionary'' citation for the figurative sense of ''literally''; the sentence from the novel used was, "He is a fortunate man to be introduced to such a party of fine women at his arrival; it is literally ''to feed among the lilies''."<ref name="languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu">[http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=5914]</ref> This citation was also used in the OED's 2011 revision.<ref name="languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu"/>
Within literary analysis, such terms are still used; but within the fields of cognition and linguistics, the basis for identifying such a distinction is no longer used.<ref name="BarberStainton2009">{{cite book|last1=Barber|first1=Alex|last2=Stainton|first2=Robert J|title=Concise Encyclopedia of Philosophy of Language and Linguistics|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2boGE2NKtpsC&pg=PA230|accessdate=23 December 2012|date=2009-11-20|publisher=Elsevier|isbn=9780080965000|pages=230–}}</ref>
==Figurative language in literary analysis== {{original research|section|date=August 2010}} Figurative language can take multiple forms, such as [[simile]] or [[metaphor]].<ref name="MontgomeryDurant2007">{{cite book|last1=Montgomery|first1=Martin|last2=Durant|first2=Alan|last3=Fabb|first3=Nigel |author4=Tom Furniss |author5=Sara Mills|title=Ways of Reading: Advanced Reading Skills for Students of English Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BhrYfYdHuN8C&pg=PA117|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=2007-01-09|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780203597118|pages=117–}}</ref> ''Merriam-Webster's Encyclopedia Of Literature'' says that figurative language can be classified in five categories: resemblance or relationship, emphasis or [[understatement]], figures of sound, verbal games, and errors.<ref name="inc1995">{{cite book|author=Merriam-Webster, inc.|title=Merriam-Webster's Encyclopedia Of Literature|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eKNK1YwHcQ4C|accessdate=23 April 2013|year=1995|publisher=Merriam-Webster|isbn=9780877790426|page=[https://books.google.com/books?id=eKNK1YwHcQ4C&pg=PA415 415]}}</ref>
A [[simile]]<ref>Origin: 1350–1400; Middle English < Latin: image, likeness, comparison, noun use of neuter of ''similis'' similar. {{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/179881|work=simile, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Simile}}</ref> is a comparison of two things, indicated by some connective, usually "like", "as", "than", or a verb such as "resembles" to show how they are similar.<ref>Kennedy, X. J., and [[Dana Gioia]]. [[An Introduction To Poetry]]. 13th ed. Longman Pub Group, 2007. Pg 594.</ref>
: Example: "His cheeks were ''like roses'', his nose ''like a cherry''.../And the beard on his chin was ''as white as the snow.''" (emph added)—Clement Clark Moore<ref name="Terbanjoi1993">{{cite book|last1=Terban|first1=Marvin|last2=joi|first2=Giulio Maestro,|title=It Figures!: Fun Figures of Speech|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Gk_Le0B46BEC&pg=PT12|accessdate=23 December 2012|year=1993|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=9780395665916|pages=12–}}</ref>
A [[metaphor]]<ref>Origin: 1525–35; < Latin ''metaphora'' < Greek ''metaphorá'' a transfer, akin to ''metaphérein'' to transfer. See meta-, -phore{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/117328|work=metaphor, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Metaphor}}</ref> is a figure of speech in which two "essentially unlike things" are shown to have a type of resemblance or create a new image.<ref name="Miller2001"/> The similarities between the objects being compared may be implied rather than directly stated.<ref name="Miller2001">{{cite book|last=Miller|first=Carol Rawlings|title=Irresistible Shakespeare: 6 Sensational Scenes from Favorite Plays and Dozens of Fun Ideas That Introduce Students to the Wonderful Works of Shakespeare|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=qT3BC2CH1LoC&pg=PA25|accessdate=23 December 2012|date=2001-03-01|publisher=Scholastic Inc.|isbn=9780439098441|pages=25–}}</ref> : Example: "Fog comes on little cat feet"—[[Carl Sandburg]]<ref name="Fandel2005">{{cite book|last=Fandel|first=Jennifer|title=Metaphors, Similes, And Other Word Pictures|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=bfWu6bCwRLcC&pg=PA30|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=2005-07-30|publisher=The Creative Company|isbn=9781583413401|pages=30–}}</ref>
An [[extended metaphor]] is a metaphor that is continued over multiple sentences.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/extended-metaphor|work=extended metaphor|publisher=Dictionary.com|title=Extended Metaphor}}</ref><ref name="Oliver1994">{{cite book|last=Oliver|first=Mary|title=Poetry Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fuBHMccJx6UC&pg=PA103|accessdate=6 March 2013|year=1994|publisher=Houghton Mifflin Harcourt|isbn=9780156724005|pages=103–}}</ref> : Example: "The sky steps out of her daywear/Slips into her shot-silk evening dress./An entourage of bats whirr and swing at her hem, ...She's tried on every item in her wardrobe." [[Dilys Rose]]<ref name="LiddellGifford2001">{{cite book|last1=Liddell|first1=Gordon F.|last2=Gifford|first2=Anne|title=New Scottish poetry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eQRs8Uz6480C&pg=PA131|accessdate=3 April 2013|date=2001-07-26|publisher=Heinemann|isbn=9780435150983|pages=131–}}</ref>
[[Onomatopoeia]] is a word designed to be an imitation of a sound.<ref>Origin: 1570–80; < Late Latin < Greek ''onomatopoiía'' making of words = onomato- (combining form of ónoma name) + poi- (stem of poieîn to make; see poet) + -ia -ia{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/131486|work=onomatopoeia, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Onomatopoeia}}</ref> : Example: “Bark! Bark!” went the dog as he chased the car that vroomed past.
[[Personification]]<ref>Origin: 1745–55; personi(fy) + -fication{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/141506|work=personification, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Personification}}</ref> is the attribution of a personal nature or character to inanimate objects or abstract notions,<ref name="Moustaki2001"/> especially as a rhetorical figure. : Example: "Because I could not stop for Death,/He kindly stopped for me;/The carriage held but just ourselves/And Immortality."—[[Emily Dickinson]]. Dickinson portrays death as a carriage driver.<ref name="Moustaki2001">{{cite book|last=Moustaki|first=Nikki|title=The Complete Idiot's Guide to Writing Poetry|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RdH3hvXEIB8C&pg=PT146|accessdate=23 December 2012|date=2001-04-01|publisher=Penguin|isbn=9781440695636|pages=146–}}</ref>
An [[oxymoron]] is a figure of speech in which a pair of opposite or contradictory terms is used together for emphasis.<ref>Origin: < post-classical Latin oxymoron, figure of speech in which a pair of opposed or markedly contradictory terms are placed in conjunction for emphasis (5th cent.; also ''oxymorum'') < ancient Greek ὀξυ-oxy- comb. form1+ μωρόςdull, stupid, foolish (see moron n.2).{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/135679|work=oxymoron|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Oxymoron}}</ref> : Examples: Organized chaos, Same difference, Bittersweet.
A [[paradox]] is a statement or proposition which is self-contradictory, unreasonable, or illogical.<ref>Origin: < Middle French, French ''paradoxe'' (1495 as noun; 1372–4 in plural ''paradoxesas'' the title of a work by Cicero; paradoxon (noun) philosophical paradox in post-classical Latin also a figure of speech < ancient Greek παράδοξον, especially in plural παράδοξαStoical paradoxes, use as noun of neuter singular of παράδοξος (adjective) contrary to received opinion or expectation < παρα-para- prefix1+ δόξαopinion (see doxology n.), after ancient Greek παρὰ δόξανcontrary to expectation{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/137353|work=paradox, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Paradox}}</ref> : Example: This statement is a lie.
[[Hyperbole]] is a figure of speech which uses an extravagant or exaggerated statement to express strong feelings.<ref>Origin: < Greek ὑπερβολήexcess (compare hyperbola n.), exaggeration; the latter sense is first found in Isocrates and Aristotle. Compare French hyperbole(earlier yperbole).{{cite web|url=http://www.oed.com.nuncio.cofc.edu/Entry/90286|work=hyperbol e, n.|publisher=Oxford English Dictionary|title=Hyperbole}}</ref> : Example: They had been walking so long that John thought he might drink the entire lake when they came upon it.
[[Allusion]] is a reference to a famous character or event. : Example: A single step can take you through the looking glass if you're not careful.
An [[idiom]] is an expression that has a figurative meaning unrelated to the literal meaning of the phrase. :Example: You should keep your eye out for him. :To keep an eye out for someone means to watch out for them.
A [[pun]] is an expression intended for a humorous or rhetorical effect by exploiting different meanings of words. : Example: I wondered why the ball was getting bigger. Then it hit me. : "Then it hit me." has two different meanings
==Standard pragmatic model of comprehension== Prior to the 1980s, the "standard pragmatic" model of comprehension was widely believed. In that model, it was thought the recipient would first attempt to comprehend the meaning as if literal, but when an appropriate literal inference could not be made, the recipient would shift to look for a figurative interpretation that would allow comprehension.<ref name="Katz1998">{{cite book|last=Katz|first=Albert N.|title=Figurative Language and Thought|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lSxhb_fZLx0C&pg=PA166|accessdate=20 December 2012|year=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780195109634|pages=166–}}</ref> Since then, research has cast doubt on the model. In tests, figurative language was found to be comprehended at the same speed as literal language; and so the premise that the recipient was first attempting to process a literal meaning and discarding it before attempting to process a figurative meaning appears to be false.<ref name="EysenckKeane2005">{{cite book|last1=Eysenck|first1=Michael William|last2=Keane|first2=Mark T.|title=Cognitive Psychology: A Student's Handbook|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=22ZWi-LVLDcC&pg=PA369|accessdate=20 December 2012|year=2005|publisher=Taylor & Francis|isbn=9781841693590|pages=369–}}</ref>
==Reddy and contemporary views== Beginning with the work of [[Michael Reddy (linguist)|Michael Reddy]] in his 1979 work "[[Conduit metaphor|The Conduit Metaphor]]", many linguists now reject that there is a valid way to distinguish between a "literal" and "figurative" mode of language.<ref name="Ortony1993">{{cite book|last=Ortony|first=Andrew|title=Metaphor and Thought|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiJRvuXA_VcC&pg=PA204|accessdate=20 December 2012|date=1993-11-26|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521405614|pages=204–}}</ref>

[[Chiapas]], [[Mexico]] | ethnicity = [[Mam people|Mam]] | speakers = 478,000 | date = 2003 | ref = e19 | familycolor = American | fam1 = [[Mayan languages|Mayan]] | fam2 = Eastern Mayan | fam3 = [[Mamean languages|Greater Mamean]] | fam4 = Mamean | minority = {{flag|Guatemala}} | iso3 = mam | glotto = mamm1241 | glottorefname = Mam | notice = IPA }} '''Mam''' is a [[Mayan languages|Mayan language]] spoken by about half a million [[Mam people]] in the [[Departments of Guatemala|Guatemalan departments]] of [[Quetzaltenango Department|Quetzaltenango]], [[Huehuetenango Department|Huehuetenango]], [[San Marcos Department|San Marcos]], and [[Retalhuleu Department|Retalhuleu]], and the [[Mexico|Mexican]] state of [[Chiapas]]. Thousands more make up a Mam diaspora throughout the [[United States]] and [[Mexico]], with notable populations living in [[Oakland, California]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.latimes.com/local/california/la-me-mayan-indigenous-languages-20160725-snap-story.html|title=Ancient Mayan languages are creating problems for today's immigration courts|last=Carcamo|first=Cindy|website=latimes.com|access-date=2018-11-24}} and [[Washington, D.C.]] ==Classification== {{see also|Mayan languages#Subdivisions}} Mam is closely related to the [[Tektitek language]], and the two languages together form the Mamean sub-branch of the Mayan language family. Along with the Ixilan languages, [[Awakatek language|Awakatek]] and [[Ixil language|Ixil]], these make up the [[Mamean languages|Greater Mamean]] sub-branch, one of the two branches of the Eastern Mayan languages (the other being the Greater Quichean sub-branch, which consists of 10 Mayan languages, including [[K'iche' language|K'iche']]). ==Dialects== Because contact between members of different Mam communities is somewhat limited, the language varies considerably even from village to village. Nevertheless, mutual intelligibility, though difficult, is possible through practice{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/748935484|title=A grammar of Mam, a Mayan language|last=England|first=Nora C.|date=1983|publisher=University of Texas Press|year=|isbn=0292729278|edition=|location=Austin|pages=|oclc=748935484}}. Mam varieties within Guatemala are divided into four dialect groups{{Cite book|title=Gramática Pedagógica Mam|last=Pérez Vail|first=Eduardo Gustavo|publisher=Instituto de Lingüística y Educación, Universidad Rafael Landívar|year=2004|isbn=|location=Guatemala|pages=}}: *'''Northern Mam''' in southern [[Huehuetenango Department]]. Northern Mam is the least conservative group according to [[Terrence Kaufman]]. *'''Southern Mam''' in [[Quetzaltenango Department]], [[San Marcos Department]], and [[Retalhuleu Department]]. *'''Central Mam''' in [[San Marcos Department]]. *'''Western Mam''' in northwestern [[San Marcos Department]]. The [[Tektitek language]] may be mutually intelligible with Western Mam dialects. In addition to these, the dialects of [[Chiapas|Chiapas, Mexico]] may form a fifth dialect group, characterised by significant grammatical as well as lexical differences from the Guatemalan varieties{{Cite book|title=Gramática Didáctica Mam: Segundo Ciclo|last=Ramos Ortíz|first=Nicacio, Juan Rolando Morales de León, Juan Rodriguez Pérez|publisher=Instituto Nacional de Lenguas Indígenas|year=2013|isbn=|location=Mexico|pages=}}. ==Distribution== Mam is spoken in 64 communities in four [[Departments of Guatemala|Guatemalan departments]]{{cite book | author = [[Academia de Lenguas Mayas de Guatemala]] | year = 2003 | title = Pujb'il Yol Mam: Vocabulario Mam}} and 18 communities in [[Chiapas|Chiapas, Mexico]]. Neighboring languages include [[Jakaltek language|Jakaltek]] and [[Q’anjob’al language|Q'anjob'al]] to the north, [[Tektitek language|Tektitek]] to the west, and [[Ixil language|Ixil]], [[Awakatek]], [[Sipakapense language|Sipacapense]], and [[K'iche' language|K'iche']] to the east. {{col-begin}} {{col-3}} '''[[Quetzaltenango Department]]''' *[[San Miguel Sigüilá]] *[[Concepción Chiquirichapa]] long:http://www.utexas.edu/utpress/books/enggra.html A Grammar of Mam, A Mayan Language, Nora C. England, University of Texas Press, page 33 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: center" ! Short ! [[Front vowel|Front]] ! [[Central vowel|Central]] ! [[Back vowel|Back]] |- ! [[Close vowel|Close]] | '''ii''' {{IPA|/iː/}} | '''u''' {{IPA|/ʉ/}} | '''uu''' {{IPA|/u͍ː/}} |- ! [[Near-close vowel|Near-Close]] | '''i''' {{IPA|/ɪ/}} | | |- ! [[Mid vowel|Mid]] | '''ee''' {{IPA|/eː/}} | | '''oo''' {{IPA|/o͍ː/}} |- ! [[Open-mid vowel|Mid-low]] | '''e''' {{IPA|/ɛ/}} | | '''o''' {{IPA|/ɔ/}} |- ! [[Open vowel|Open]] | |'''a''' {{IPA|/ä/}} |'''aa''' {{IPA|/ɑ͍ː/}} |} *The Mid-central vowel is an allophone of short a, e and u that can occur in the syllable following a stressed long vowel. Like in many other Mayan languages, [[vowel length]] is contrastive, and short and long vowels have different phonemic values and are treated as separate vowels. The long versions of the back vowels, /o/, /u/, /ɑ/ vowels, transcribed as '''[oo]''', '''[uu]''', and '''[aa]''' are slightly compressed and pronounced as /o͍ː/, /u͍ː/, and /ɑ͍ː/ respectively, being partially rounded. In the Todos Santos dialect the vowel structure is somewhat different. While /o/, /a/, and /u/ remain the same as in other varieties, short /e/ has become the diphthong /ɛi/, an audio example of this can be heard here:{{Cite video | url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j2WZsDB2LHM | people = | title = Speaking in MAM | medium = streaming video | publisher = YouTube | location = Todos Santos, Guatemala | date = 2009}} In the Todos Santos dialect, the long vowels (distinguished by the doubling of the letter) have evolved into separate sounds altogether. Long /aː/ has become /ɒ/, long /oː/ has become /øː/ and long /uː/ has become /yː/. In some dialects vowels interrupted by stop have evolved into individual phonemes themselves, for example in Todos Santos dialect /oʔ/ represented by o' has evolved into /ɵʏˀ/ and /oʔo/ represented by o'o has evolved into /ɵ'ʉ/. ===Consonants=== Mam has 27 [[consonant]]s, including the [[glottal stop]]: {| class="wikitable" |- align=center ! rowspan="2" colspan="3" | ! rowspan="2" | [[Bilabial consonant|Bilabial]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Alveolar consonant|Alveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Postalveolar consonant|Postalveolar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Retroflex consonant|Retroflex]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Palatal consonant|Palatal]] ! colspan="2" | [[Velar consonant|Velar]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Uvular consonant|Uvular]] ! rowspan="2" | [[Glottal consonant|Glottal]] |- ! Plain ! In the Todos Santos dialect it is pronounced as [v] as part of a consonant cluster and as [βv̻] word finally. : Examples: '''tzeb'''' [tsɛβʼ] ''goat'', '''kbon''' [kβʼɤŋ] ''small table''. In the Todos Santos dialect, '''tseb'''' is [tsɛiβv̻] and '''kbon''' is [kvoŋ] ''small table''. /p/ is realized as [pʰ] word-finally and word initially, [p] elsewhere, [ɸ] in a consonant cluster and before short i, o, and u. It is pronounced as [ɸʰ] word finally in certain dialects. [f] is an interchangeable pronunciation of [ɸ]. : Examples: '''piich''' [pʰiːt͡ʃ] ''bird'', '''txkup''' [ʈ͡ʂkʰɯpʰ] or [ʈ͡ʂkʰɯɸʰ] ''animal'' , '''ptz'an''' [pʰt͡sʼaŋ] or [ɸʰt͡sʼaŋ] ''sugarcane''. /ch/ has evolved from /tʃ/ to /sʃ/ in most Mexican dialects and some northern Guatemalan dialects. Sometimes the /t/ sound is still lightly pronounced before the stressed /sʃ/ sound. : Example: '''choot''' [tʃʰoːtʰ] '''weeds''' has evolved into [sʃøːtʰ] or [tsʃoːtʰ] /t/ is realized as [tʰ] word-finally and before another consonant, [t] elsewhere. : Examples: '''ta'l''' [taʔl̥] ''juice, soup'', '''ch'it''' [t͡ʃʼɪtʰ] ''bird'', '''q'ootj''' [ʛoːtʰχ] ''dough'' /k/ is realized as [kʰ] word-finally and before another consonant, [k] elsewhere. : Examples: '''paaki'l''' [pɑːkɪʔl̥] ''butterfly'', '''xtook''' [ʂtʰoːkʰ] ''staff'', '''kjo'n''' [kʰχɤʔŋ] ''cornfield'' /w/ can be pronounced [ʋ], [v], [v̥] or [β] word initially, [w], [ʍ] [ʋ] following a consonant, and [ʋ], [v], [v̻ʰ] or [fʰ] word finally. It is freely variable between [w] [v] [ʋ] [v̥] in all other positions with [ʋ] being the most common pronunciation. In the Todos Santos dialect, /w/ is realized as either [v] or [ʋ] word-initially or between vowels and before another consonant, as [ʍ] following a consonant and as [v̥] word finally. : Examples: '''waaj''' [ʋɑːχ], [vɑːχ], [v̥ɑːχ], or [βɑːχ]''tortilla'', '''twon''' [twɤŋ], [tʍɤŋ], [tʋɤŋ] ''introversion'', '''lew''' [lɛʋ], [lɛv] [lɛv̥ʰ] [lɛfʰ] ''care''. /q/ is realized as [qʰ] word-finally and before another consonant, [q] elsewhere. : Examples: '''muuqin'''' [muːqɪŋ] ''tortilla'', '''aaq''' [ɑːqʰ] ''honeycomb'', '''qloolj''' [qʰɺoːlχ] ''obscurity'' /tʼ/ is realized interchangeably as [tʼ] and [ɗ] word-initially and -finally, after a vowel or before [l]. : Examples: '''t'rikpuul''' [tʼɾɪkʰɸuːl̥] ~ [ɗɾɪkʰpuːl̥] ''to jump'', '''ch'uut''' [t͡ʃʼuːtʼ] ~ [t͡ʃʼuːɗ] ''something sharp-pointed'' : Examples: '''t'ut'an''' [tʼɯtʼaŋ] ~ [ɗɯɗaŋ] ''wet'', '''wit'li''' [vɪtʼli] ~ [vɪɗli] ''seated squatting'' /n/ is realized as [ŋ] before [[velar consonant|velar-]] and [[uvular consonant]]s and word-finally,
as [ɲ] before [j] and as [m] before /ɓ/ and /p/, [n] elsewhere. : Examples: '''nim''' [nɪm] ''much'', '''juun''' [χuːŋ] ''one'', '''q'ankyoq''' [ʛaŋkʲɤqʰ] ''thunder'' : Examples: '''saajel''' [sɑːŋχel̥] ''sent'', '''nyuxh''' [ɲɯʃ] ''my godfather'' : Examples: '''qanb'ax''' [qamɓaʂ] ''foot'', '''npwaaqe''' [mpwɑːqɛ] ''my money'' /l/ is realized as [l̥] word-finally, [ɺ] before short vowels and after plosives, bilabial, aveolar and retroflex consonants and [l] elsewhere. : Examples: '''luux''' [luːʂ] ''cricket'', '''lo'l''' [ɺoʔl̥] ''to eat fruits'', '''wlat''' [vɺatʰ] ''stiff''. /ky/ is realized as [kɕʲ] in front of another consonant and kɕʰ word finally. It is pronounced as kʲ in all other instances. : Examples: '''kyja'tzan''' [kɕʲχaʲʔtsʰaŋ], '''kyokleen''' [kʲɤkleːŋ] / ' / is realized as [ʲʔ] following /a/, /aa/, /e/, /ee/, /i/, /u/, /uu/ and /oo/. The standard pronunciation is simply [ʔ] after all vowels however in spoken speech [ʲʔ] is the common pronunciation. A similar trend can be seen in other Eastern Mayan languages. After /o/ it is pronounced as [ʉʔ] and after /ii/ it is pronounced simply as [ʔ]. Following consonants / ' / modifies each individual consonant differently as explained in the section above. In the Mam language every word must start with a consonant. In the current orthography initial / ' / is not written but if a word ever begins with a vowel, the word is treated as if it begin with a / ' /. The initial / ' / may be pronounced as either [ʔ] or [ʡ] in free variation. ==Grammar== The most extensive Mam grammar is that of Nora C. England's ''A grammar of Mam, a Mayan language'' (1983), which is based on the [[San Ildefonso Ixtahuacán]] dialect of [[Huehuetenango Department]]. The basic word order of Mam is [[Verb–subject–object|VSO]] (Verb-Subject-Object, Verb-Ergative-Absolutive, or Verb-Agent-Patient). Most roots take the morphological shape CVC (England 1983:93). The only possible root final consonant cluster is -''nC''. ===Pronouns=== Mam has no independent pronouns (England 1983:155). Rather, pronouns in Mam always exist as [[bound morpheme]]s. The grammar of the constructed [[Na'vi language]] was created for the movie ''[[Avatar (2009 film)|Avatar]]'' by [[Paul Frommer]]. It is a [[tripartite language|tripartite]], primarily affixing [[agglutinative]] language.
== Morphophonology == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Phonology}}
===Lenition=== [[Lenition]] is a phonological change that is the result of the application of certain prefixes:<ref>Frommer (Language Log), Phonetics and Phonology: 5. Phonetic detail and phonology: Lenition</ref> *px (/p‘/) → p *tx (/t‘/) → t *kx (/k‘/) → k *p → f *t or ts → s *k → h *' (/ʔ/) → ∅ Conventional notation uses + to denote a prefix that causes lenition.<ref>Miller, p.1</ref>
=== Other effects === Since Na'vi does not make the distinction between long and short vowels,<ref>Annis, § 2.1.4.3</ref> if the application of an affix results in two of the same vowels in a row, it usually is shortened to one.<ref>Annis, § 2.3.1</ref><ref group="Note">See exception with '''-ey-''' in the noun section</ref> There is also some nasal assimilation of place.<ref>Annis, § 2.3.4</ref> Specific affixes listed hereafter will list there variants. Many prefixes combine with each other to form slight variants
==Nouns== {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Nouns}}
===Prefixes===
==== Plural ==== Na'vi has a singular, dual, trial and plural number. The dual prefix is '''me+''', the trial is '''pxe+''' and the general plural '''ay+'''. All of these prefixes cause lenition.<ref>Annis, § 3.1.3</ref> If the '''ay+''' prefix causes a word to undergo lenition, the prefix may be dropped and the modified stem is also considered the general plural, and is known as the short plural<ref>Frommer (Language Log), Word Classes and Morphology: 1. Nouns: Number: Short plurals</ref> *'''tute''' ''person'' → '''aysute''' ''people'' → '''sute''' ''people'' The prefix '''fra-''' indicates means "every".<ref>Annis, § 3.3.4</ref>
==== Deixis ==== The prefix '''fì-''' indicates proximal [[deixis]]. When used as a plural, it becomes '''fay+'''.<ref>Annis § 3.3.1</ref> '''payoang''' ''fish'' → '''fìpayoang''' ''this fish'' The prefix '''tsa-''' indicates distal dexis. When used as a plural, it becomes '''tsay+'''.<ref>Annis § 3.3.2</ref>
==== Other ==== There is also the prefix '''fne-''' which means a type, sort or class of the noun it is attached to.
=== Suffixes === The suffix '''-o''' marks the noun as indefinite (i.e. "some"). *'''’eylan''' ''friend'' → '''’eylano''' ''some friend'' The suffix '''-tsyìp''' is used as a [[diminutive]]/endearment suffix.<ref name="dim">{{cite web |url=http://naviteri.org/2010/07/diminutives-conversational-expressions/ |title= Diminutives; Conversational Expressions | Naviteri.org |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=11 July 2010 |website=www.naviteri.org |accessdate=12 July 2013 }}</ref> *'''utral''' ''tree'' → '''utraltsyìp''' ''bush'' The suffix '''-fkeyk''' make the noun refers to the state of the noun to which it is attached.<ref name="MillerH">Miller, Appendix. H</ref>
==== Gender ==== Na'vi does not have grammatical gender, but it has two suffixes that indicate the gender of a noun: the feminine suffix '''-e''' and the masculine suffix '''-an'''.<ref>Annis, § 5.8.1.4</ref> These are not mandatory. *'''karyu''' ''teacher'' → '''karyuan''' ''male teacher'' *'''karyu''' ''teacher'' → '''karyue''' ''female teacher''
=== Cases === Na'vi is a tripartite language which means that the subject of an intransitive verb takes the [[intransitive case]]. The subject of a transitive verb takes the [[ergative case]], which is '''-l''' on nouns ending with vowels and '''-ìl''' on nouns ending with consontants. The object of a transitive verb takes the [[accusative]] case, which is ''-t'' on nouns that end with a vowel and ''-ìt''<ref name="3.1.1">Annis § 3.1.1</ref>
Example: '''oel ngati tse’a''' {| |'''oe<u>l</u>''' || '''nga<u>ti</u>''' || tse'a |- |''I.ERG'' || ''you.ACC'' || ''to see'' |} :I see you The [[dative]] case is '''-r''' or '''-ru''' on nouns ending with a vowel, and '''-ìr''' on nouns ending with a consonant. The [[genitive]] case is '''-yä''', except on nouns ending with o or u, where it is '''-ä''', or nouns ending with '''-ia''' that become '''-iä'''. The [[Topic-comment|topical]] case is '''-ri''' on nouns ending with a vowel, and '''-ìri''' on nouns ending with a vowel.<ref name="3.1.1" />
=== Nominalizers === The suffix '''-yu''' turns a verb into an agent noun. *'''slele''' ''to swim'' → '''sleleyu''' ''swimmer'' The prefix '''tì''', in combination with the infix '''-us-''', forms the gerund.<ref name="dim" /> The suffix '''-tswo''' creates a noun indicating the ability to do the verb.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://naviteri.org/2012/03/spring-vocabulary-part-2/ |title= Spring Vocabulary, Part 2 | Na’viteri.org |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=31 March 2012 |website=www.naviteri.org |accessdate=12 July 2013 }}</ref>
== Verbs == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Verbs}} Na'vi verbs primarily use affixes to modify their meaning. They do not conjugate for person, but for tense. Each affix has a specific location.
===Positions=== When an infix is added to a Na'vi syllable, the infix goes after the initial consonant but before the vowel. There are three positions where an infix is added: the pre-first preposition, which goes immediately before the first position, the first position, which goes in the penultimate syllable, and the second position, which goes in the final syllable. If the verb is monosyllabic, all three positions go after each other. If the verb is a compound, the infixes only go in the head<ref>Annis, § 3.6.1.4.</ref>
=== Pre-first position ===
==== Causative ==== The causative infix is '''-eyk-'''. When a causative verb is used, the ergative becomes the dative, and the accusative remains as it is.<ref>Annis § 6.1.1.2</ref>
==== Reflexive ==== The reflexive infix is '''-äp-'''. When it is used with '''-eyk-''', it always comes first ('''-äpeyk-''')
=== 1st position ===
==== Tense infixes ==== There are four types of tense infixes, which mark for the past, near past, general, near future and future tenses, and that mark for the general, imperfective, and perfective aspects<ref>Annis § 3.6.3</ref> The first type are the regular ones {| class="wikitable" |- ! N/A !! Past !! Near past !! General !! Near future !! Future |- | '''General''' ||-am- || -ìm- || -∅- || -ìy- || -ay- |- | '''Perfective''' ||-alm- || -ìlm- || -ol- || -ìly- || -aly- |- | '''Imperfective ''' ||-arm- || -ìrm- || -er- || -ìry || -ary- |} There are two future intent infixes.<ref>Annis § 3.6.3.1</ref> {| class="wikitable" ! Near Future !! Future |- | -ìsy- || -asy- |} There are also a few subjunctive infixes {| class="wikitable" |- ! Past !! General !! Future !! Perfective !! Imperfective |- | -imv- || -iv- || -iyev- (or -ìyev) || -ilv- || -irv- |}
==== Modal verbs ==== Na'vi has a few modal verbs, which when used, they must take the tense affixes and the modified verb must take the general subjunctive. The subject of the modal verb takes the intransitive case.<ref>Annis § 6.8.3.1-3</ref>
Example: '''’emyu new syuvet ayfol yivom''' {| |- | '''’emyu''' || '''new''' || '''syuvet''' || '''ayfol''' || '''y<u>iv</u>om''' |- | ''chef''.INTR || ''want'' || ''food''.ERG || ''them''.ERG || ''eat''.SBJV |} : The chef wanted them to eat the food
===2nd position=== There are four infixes in this category, two indicating affect, two indicating speaker judgement. The infix '''-ei-''' indicate that the speaker is happy about the verb. The infix '''-äng-''' indicates that the speaker is unhappy about the verb.<ref>Annis § 3.6.4</ref> The variant '''-eiy-''' of '''-ei-''' is used behind i,ì, ll, and rr<ref>Annis, § 2.3.3</ref> and the variant '''-eng-''' of '''-äng-''' is used behind i<ref>Annis § 2.3.5.2</ref>
The infix '''-ats-''' is used to indicate that the speaker is uncertain of the accuracy of his or her statement. There is also the [[honorifics (linguistics)|honorific]] infix '''-uy-'''.<ref name="MillerH" />
===Suffixes===
== Adjectives == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Adjectives}} Adjectives are created with the '''-a-''' affix. Adjectives can go before or after the noun that they modify. If the ajective is before the noun '''-a''' becomes a suffix, and if the adjective is after the noun, '''a-''' becomes a prefix.<ref>Annis §</ref> Compare the two ways of saying ''the long river'' ('''kilvan''' ''river'', '''ngim''' ''long'') :ngim'''a''' kilvan and :kilvan '''a'''ngim
=== Participles === Na'vi has an active participle infix '''-us-''', and the passive participle infix '''-awn-'''<ref>Annis, § 3.6.3.3</ref>
=== Ability adjectives === There are two prefixes that mark ability '''tsuk-''' indicates that the subject (ergative) is able to perform the verb. It is negated with '''ke-'''. These turn a verb into an adjective <ref>{{cite web |url=http://naviteri.org/2011/03/%E2%80%9Creceptive-ability%E2%80%9D-and-hesitation/ |title= "Receptive Ability" and Hesitation | Naviteri.org |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=22 March 2009 |website=www.naviteri.org |accessdate=11 July 2013 }}</ref>
=== From nouns === Nouns can be turned into adjective modifiers with the prefix '''le-'''. If this kind of adjective is used after the noun in question, the '''a-''' affix is usually dropped.<ref>Annis, § 3.5.1.1</ref> When it is used is after the prefix '''ke-''' they become '''kel-'''. If the '''ke-''' goes before '''le-''', they become '''kel-'''.<ref>Annis, § 5.1.2.1-2</ref>
=== Copula === The Na'vi copula is the verb '''lu'''. They can be linked to nouns or adjectives. Number is only required to be declared once in a phrase involving '''lu'''<ref>{{cite web |url=http://naviteri.org/2011/07/number-in-na%E2%80%99vi/ |title= Number in Na'vi | Naviteri.org |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=30 July 2011 |website=www.naviteri.org |accessdate=16 August 2013 }}</ref> Adjectives linked with '''lu''' are not required to have the '''-a-''' affix The verb '''lu''' can also be used in the sense of '''having'''. In this case, the possessor takes the dative suffix.<ref>Annis, § 6.4.4.3</ref>
Example: '''lu poru tstxo''' {| |'''lu''' || '''po<u>ru</u>''' || '''tstxo''' |- |''to be'' || ''3SG.DAT'' || ''name'' |} :s/he has a name
== Questions == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Questions}}
=== Yes–no === [[Yes–no question]]s are formed with the word '''srak(e)''', which can go at the beginning or end of a clause (It has no e if it occurs at the end of a clause.
=== Pe question === The affix '''-pe+''' is used to form question words when attached to a noun, which means which. It can go before or after the noun, and it causes lenition if placed before the noun. If it is a prefix, and the noun is plural, they will combine and become '''pem+''' (dual), '''pep+''' (trial) or '''pay+''' (plural). *
== Pronouns == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Pronouns}} Na'vi pronouns have the same declension as any other noun. The pronouns are declined for four persons: 1st person inclusive, 1st person exclusive, 2nd person, and 3rd person animate. Most of the plural forms of the various pronouns are made from the addition of the number prefixes to the singular. {| class="wikitable" |- ! <ref>Annis, § 3.2.2</ref> !! Singular !! Dual !! Trial !! plural |- | '''1st exclusive''' || oe || moe || pxoe || ayoe |- | '''1st inclusive''' || N/A || oeng || pxoeng || ayoeng |- | '''2nd person''' || nga || menga || pxenga || aynga |- | '''3rd animate''' || po || mefo || pxefo || ayfo/fo |} The singular inanimate 3rd person is '''tsa'u''', the demonstrative pronoun. The reflexive pronoun is '''sno''', and the indefinite personal pronoun is '''fko'''.<ref>Annis, § 3.2.2.7-9</ref>
== Adpositions == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Adpositions}} Adpositions may go before or after the noun they modify. If it is before, then it is a separate word, but if after they are attach to the noun they modify.
== Relative clauses == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Syntax}} Relative clauses are formed with the particle '''a'''. If the [[Head (linguistics)|head]] noun is the ergative or accusative of the phrase it modifies, it is not present in the relative clause. If the head of the relative clause uses any other case or adposition, a [[resumptive pronoun]] is used.<ref>Annis, § 6.18.1-2</ref>
== Conditionals == A conditional is use the words '''txo''' and '''tsakrr'''. The condidion goes after '''txo''', and takes the [[subjunctive]] case, then the consequent goes after the '''tsakrr''' (which is often omitted) and takes the relevant case.<ref>Annis, § 6.19.1-2</ref><ref name="counterfact">{{cite web |url=http://naviteri.org/2013/04/zun-zel-counterfactual-conditionals/ |title= Zun . . . Zel: Counterfactual Conditionalss | Naviteri.org |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=30 April 2013 |website=www.naviteri.org |accessdate=16 August 2013 }}</ref> A counter-factual conditional uses the words '''zun''' for the condition and '''zel''' for the consequent, and uses the subjunctive in both clauses<ref name="counterfact" /><!-- Add info about the use of the various subjunctives -->
== Numbers == {{wikibooks|Na'vi/Numbers}} Na'vi's native number system is an [[octal]] one. The numbers 0-7, 10<sub>8</sub> (8), and 100<sub>8</sub> (64) are<ref name="MillerA">Miller, Appendix A</ref> {| class="wikitable" |- ! 0 !! 1 !! 2 !! 3 !! 4 !! 5 !! 6 !! 7 !! 10<sub>8</sub> !! 100<sub>8</sub> |- | kew || 'aw || mune || pxey || tsìng || mrr || pukap || kinä || vol || zam |}
The powers of eight are combined with special prefixes to create multiples of powers of eight. These are the first syllable of the corresponding number, except for 1, which has none, and 2, which has '''me-''' instead of '''mu-'''. To create a number that is a power of eight plus a number from 1 to 7, the ''l'' of '''vol''' is deleted (except for 1), and the initial consonant undergoes lenition.<ref>Annis, § 4.1.*</ref>
Ordinals of the aforementioned numbers can be formed with the suffix '''-ve''', but there are a few irregularities<ref>Annis § 4.2.1</ref>
Na'vi also has the numbers ''''eyt''' ''eight'' and '''nayn''' ''nine'' as loanwords from English.<ref name="MillerA" />
== Sources == *{{cite web |url=http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=1977 |title= Language Log » Some highlights of Na’vi |last=Frommer |first=Paul |date=19 December 2009 |website=Language Log |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130620023405/http://languagelog.ldc.upenn.edu/nll/?p=1977 |archivedate=20 June 2013 |accessdate=11 July 2013}} *{{cite book |last=Annis |first=William S. |title= Horen Lì’fyayä leNa’vi: A Reference Grammar of Na’vi |url=http://files.learnnavi.org/docs/horen-lenavi.pdf|accessdate=June 2, 2013}} *''Na'vi Dictionary'', Edited by Mark Miller
